name: POTASSIUM CHLORIDE - ORAL POTASSIUM
breadcrumbs: 9.2.1 Oral preparations for fluid and electrolyte imbalance
cautions:
Cautions 
(From 9.2.1.1 Oral potassium: British National Formulary)
9.2.1.1 Oral potassium; cardiac disease; elderly; with modified-release
preparations, intestinal stricture, history of peptic
ulcer, hiatus hernia; interactions: Appendix 1 (potassium salts)
side-effects:
Side-effects nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, flatulence; with modified-release preparations, gastro-intestinal obstruction,
ulceration and bleeding also reported
doses:
Do not confuse Effervescent Potassium Tablets
BPC 1968 (section 9.2.1.3) with effervescent potassium chloride tablets. Effervescent Potassium Tablets BPC 1968 do not contain
chloride ions and their use should be restricted to hyperchloraemic
states (section 9.2.1.3).

name: POTASSIUM CHLORIDE - INTRAVENOUS POTASSIUM
breadcrumbs: 9.2.2 Parenteral preparations for fluid and electrolyte imbalance
cautions:
Cautions for intravenous infusion the concentration
of solution should not usually exceed 3 g (40 mmol)/litre; specialist advice and ECG monitoring (
(From Intravenous potassium: British National Formulary)
Potassium chloride and sodium chloride intravenous infusion is the initial treatment for the correction of severe hypokalaemia and when sufficient potassium cannot be taken by mouth. Ready-mixed infusion solutions should be used when possible; alternatively, potassium chloride concentrate, as ampoules containing 1.5 g (K+ 20 mmol) in 10 mL, is thoroughly mixed with 500 mL of sodium chloride 0.9% intravenous infusion and given slowly over 2 to 3 hours, with specialist advice and ECG monitoring in difficult cases. Higher concentrations of potassium chloride may be given in very severe depletion, but require specialist advice.Repeated measurement of plasma-potassium concentration is necessary to determine whether further infusions are required and to avoid the development of hyperkalaemia, which is especially likely in renal impairment.Initial potassium replacement therapy should not involve glucose infusions, because glucose may cause a further decrease in the plasma-potassium concentration.); interactions: Appendix 1 (potassium salts)
side-effects: Side-effects rapid infusion toxic to heart
doses:
By slow intravenous infusion, depending
on the deficit or the daily maintenance requirements, see also notes
above
